White is better developed in that he's already castled, but Black's pieces are more active.

The natural move -- but it allows Black to unleash a ferocious assault.
A sacrifice to open lines pointing at White's King.
White goes by Steinitz's rule: the best way to refute a sacrifice is to accept it. But now his King's defences are blasted open.
If White plays 14 hxg4???, the response is 14... hxg4#

White's desperate counter-attack begins. If it fails, Black will drive through to mate.
Brilliant play. If White succumbs to the temptation of 20 Qxd7???, there follows 20...Qxf1+ 21 Kh2 Qf4+ 22 Kg1 Bxd6!!! 23 Qf5+ Qxf5 24 exf5 Bg3!!! and mate is forced.

White resigns. His undeveloped Queen-side pieces have no more than statistical value, and the threat of 25...Qh2# cannot be stopped without massive loss of material. If white tries 25 Kg1, there follows 25... Qh2+ 26 Kf1 Be2+ and mate is only a matter of moves.
